page.title: 01ABERLADY BAY
page.content:
Aberlady Bay and its environs to the north and east form the nature reserve. It was the first local reserve of its kind to be established in Scotland. The reserve has an area of over 1000 acres (450 hectares) and is a favourite wintering place for wild geese and host to a large number of birds which nest there in the summer.
The sea laps almost to the edge of the main road to Gullane at high tide but there are fears that this will not continue for much longer as the Bay is progressively silting-up. The most obvious candidate, the Peffer Burn, is not the main culprit.
